citations.desc: Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee (IACUC).
citations.narrative:
The written narratives for Protocols 201700811 and 201900151 described a literature search for alternatives focusing on
the science being studied, but the search did not address all of the painful/distressful procedures described in the
protocols. Both protocols describe surgery that involves a craniotomy and the use of meloxicam for pain during/after the
procedure. Both protocols also involve the use of foot shocks in behavior testing. The consideration of alternatives for
both protocols did not address the craniotomy procedure and one protocol, 201900151, also did not address alternatives
to the foot shock procedure.
The searches were therefore not adequate to determine that alternatives were not available. In order to approve proposed
activities, the IACUC shall determine that the principal investigator has considered alternatives to procedures that may
cause more than momentary or slight pain or distress to the animals and has provided a written narrative description of
the methods and sources used to determine that alternatives were not available. Correct by 6/21/23.

According to IACUC records, on December 2, 2022, a facility staff member found a dead vole in a freezer outside of a
plastic bag. Based on an internal investigation of six voles that had been through euthanasia procedures and frozen in a
bag on a previous date, it was determined that the euthanasia procedures had been incomplete, and therefore the facility
did not handle that animal in accordance with this section of the regulations. The facility instituted appropriate retraining
and other staff changes after concluding their internal investigation. All animals shall be handled as expeditiously and
carefully as possible so as not to cause trauma, excessive cooling, behavioral stress, physical harm or unnecessary
discomfort. Corrected prior to this inspection.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
Additional Inspectors:
SUSANNE BRUNKHORST, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
2.31(d)(1)(ii) 
   
Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee (IACUC). 
The written narratives for Protocols 201700811 and 201900151 described a literature search for alternatives focusing on 
the science being studied, but the search did not address all of the painful/distressful procedures described in the 
protocols. Both protocols describe surgery that involves a craniotomy and the use of meloxicam for pain during/after the 
procedure. Both protocols also involve the use of foot shocks in behavior testing. The consideration of alternatives for 
both protocols did not address the craniotomy procedure and one protocol, 201900151, also did not address alternatives 
to the foot shock procedure. 
 
The searches were therefore not adequate to determine that alternatives were not available. In order to approve proposed 
activities, the IACUC shall determine that the principal investigator has considered alternatives to procedures that may 
cause more than momentary or slight pain or distress to the animals and has provided a written narrative description of 
the methods and sources used to determine that alternatives were not available. Correct by 6/21/23. 
2.38(f)(1)  Critical
   
Miscellaneous.

According to IACUC records, on December 2, 2022, a facility staff member found a dead vole in a freezer outside of a 
plastic bag. Based on an internal investigation of six voles that had been through euthanasia procedures and frozen in a 
bag on a previous date, it was determined that the euthanasia procedures had been incomplete, and therefore the facility 
did not handle that animal in accordance with this section of the regulations.  The facility instituted appropriate retraining 
and other staff changes after concluding their internal investigation. All animals shall be handled as expeditiously and 
carefully as possible so as not to cause trauma, excessive cooling, behavioral stress, physical harm or unnecessary 
discomfort. Corrected prior to this inspection. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
SUSANNE BRUNKHORST, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n
